awd_titl_txt: CAREER: New Directions in Graph Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
Networks such as the Internet, social networks, transportation maps, and communication backbones have an ubiquitous presence in modern life. Graph algorithms play a crucial role in these networks by providing a range of basic services such as navigation, traffic management, and robustness against physical failures. Moreover, graphs are useful in modeling interactions in a variety of systems that arise in physical, biological, and social sciences. This project identifies a set of common themes in the algorithmic challenges that arise in modern networks -- uncertainty of data, complex failure patterns, and gigantic scale -- and seeks generic solutions that address these core issues. The project is expected to provide new insights into classical graph optimization problems, while also creating new models, problem formulations, and research directions that embrace these broad challenges. This project will also train graduate and undergraduate researchers in theoretical computer science, with an emphasis on gender diversity and participation of underrepresented groups. 

For over fifty years, graph algorithms have played a central role in the advancement of computer science, both in theory and practice. Modern networks have evolved in scale, structure, and functionality, inspiring new models, problems, and algorithms. This project focuses on three key research thrusts for modern graph algorithms:  (a) network design under unreliable or imprecise future predictions, by developing generic optimization techniques for uncertain and dynamic inputs; (b) the analysis of correlation effects in network failures by expanding the scope of classical metrics like minimum cuts to incorporate correlated failures of multiple network components; and (c) the design of highly efficient algorithms for large networks, focusing on the tradeoff between approximation and efficiency for fundamental graph optimization problems. The project will integrate tools from diverse areas such as combinatorial optimization, probability theory, mathematical programming, and continuous optimization to model and address these algorithmic questions, and the project is expected to shed new light on related questions in these domains as well.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on designing state of the art algorithms in the area of graph connectivity. Of particular interest was the problem of minimum cut, which is a foundational question in the field of combinatorial optimization. The project succeeded in designing improved algorithms for the minimum cut problem both in directed and undirected graphs - these marked the first improvements for these problems in over two decades. The novel techniques that were developed for these results had wider impact - it led to new exact and approximation algorithms for a wide variety of related problems such as all-pairs minimum cuts, minimum Steiner cut, vertex connectivity, connectivity augmentation, and network unreliability problems. Many of these results marked the first improvements for these problems after decades. Overall, the project led to the publication of nearly 20 papers in leading conference in theoretical computer science: FOCS, STOC, SODA, and ICALP. Several of these papers were invited to special issues of journal volumes dedicated to publishing the top papers at the conference. In addition to core graph algorithms research, the PI alsow worked on graph algorithms with applications to other related fields, such as machine learning and robust optimization, and these led to an exchange of ideas and techniques between these different areas. The result sobtained in these collaborative research efforts were disseminated in venues such as ICML and AAAI, which are leading conferences in machine learning and articial intelligence respectively. In summary, the project led to the development of new techniques for fundamental problems in graph algorithms and also helped bridge graph algorithms with other adjacent fields.

 

In addition to technical results, the project led to the research training of a large number of graduate and undergraduate students at Duke University. The PI's graduate students Ruoxu Cen, Lu Wang, and Samuel Haney, and undergraduate students Arun Ganesh and William He contributed to several results in this project and were partially funded by it. In addition, the project helped provide research experience to other undergraduate students at Duke by complimenting the exisiting summer research program in the computer science department (called the CS+ program). The PI also taught advanced classes in graph algorithms attended by a diverse set of graduate and undergraduate students, where contemporary topics in graph algorithms were discussed in detail including some of the results obtained in this project. The lectures notes for these courses are freely available on the internet. The PI also gave many lectures in universities, research labs, and workshop venues across the world on graph algorithms developed in this project, therbey leading to wide dissemination of the results, techniques, and ideas resulting from this project.
